abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is highly
            unsatisfactory, sustainability highly unlikely, and
            institutional development impacts are negligible.
            Consequently, the performance of the borrower is rated
            highly unsatisfactory, primarily due to the inability to
            meet its commitments to initiate improvements in Electricite
            du Liban (EdL) operations, and financial management, and, to
            introduce legislation restructuring, and privatizing the
            sector, as agreed under the Action Plan. Similarly, the Bank
            performance is rated unsatisfactory, due to serious flaws in
            project design, inadequate back-up plans to improve
            EdL's financial viability, and management, and lack of
            integrated investment programs for the medium, and high
            voltage transmission lines, among others. Lessons of general
            experience suggest that legal, and institutional reforms be
            implemented prior to Bank commitments; consideration be
            given to the inclusion of cross effectiveness conditions
            with major lending institutions, when integrated
            transmission systems require completion of all components to
            be fully effective - this could have greatly increased
            incentives for the Government to schedule a timely approval
            of the financial package; technology issues need to be
            reviewed, and resolved prior to Board presentation, which
            could have avoided the long, drawn-out procurement of the
            Baalbeck and Saida transformer substations. Lessons
            specifically for Bank lending in Lebanon, suggest particular
            consideration to the use of the Council for Development and
            Reconstruction, as the project procurement organization,
            whenever the procurement process of implementing agencies
            require several layers of internal, and external formal
            approval; and, monitorable institutional processes should be
            considered to ensure access to local financial resources,
            required for expropriations, and resettlement issues.
